results.title: Stories from the earth
results.creator_credit: Katie Jennings and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Fire on the rim”.
In days long gone, the lack of factual explanation for the eruptions, quakes and ancilliary disasters throughout the “ring of fire”, gave rise to myths and legends as means of coping with the impact of the erratic disturbances. Cultures both old and new have been partly shaped by such events, producing beliefs affecting the social behaviour of people living with the unpredictability of the earth. This program examines some of the fascinating stories that have emerged in these communitites.

results.title: Celebrations: christmas
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
Narrated by Eileen Darley, this program aimed at young children looks at the celebrations surrounding Christmas. It follows the signs and symbols that signify Christmas is near, such as shopping, store and street decorations, advent calendars, parades, sending cards, making your own gifts, decorating trees, the importance of being with people you love, and being charitable to those in need. The program also looks at the origins of Christmas trees and cards, and the story of the first Christmas. Delicious traditional Christmas fare from Italy and Germany are also shown. Suitable for children 4-8.

results.title: Fire into gold
results.creator_credit: Katie Jennings and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Fire on the rim”.
The lands around the “ring of fire” have long attracted people by their beauty, natural riches and promise of great wealth, despite the perilious threat of natural disaster. In Bali, volcanoes have created fertile lands, whereas in Papua New Guinea, centuries of activity have resulted in a gold mountain, the richest mine in the world. In contrast, the movement of the earth’s plates have resulted in the geothermic pools and geysers in New Zealand, which have become popular tourist attractions, as have the famous volcanoes of Hawaii.

results.title: Weather: rain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This video is mostly a visual exploration of rain as it falls on a rain forest. There is a child with yellow rain coat and rain hat walking through the rain and speaking of the rain and how things can be appreciated differently as it falls. The water rushes and runs gathering in streams. The child visits the zoo to watch the animals in the rain who don’t seem as fussed about the rain as humans do, drinking from the sky. The child ends up in the playground enjoying the rain here also.

results.title: Kind Hearts and Coronets
results.creator_credit: Robert Hamer, Sir Michael Balcon and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
A genteel mass-murderer is out to heartlessly eliminate the eight relatives standing between him and the family fortune. Alec Guinness plays all eight victims in this witty black comedy. Based on the novel “Noblesse oblige” by Roy Horniman.

results.title: Preparing for disaster
results.creator_credit: Katie Jennings and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Fire on the rim”.
People have devised many methods of surviving the upheavals in the “ring of fire”. In Alaska, earthquakes are so extreme, that it is an ideal location for continuous research. In Chile and Hawaii, research focuses on ocean and tidal problems. Japan and New Zealand offer insight into anti-quake designs. In San Francisco, planning, communication, training and organisation have assisted in reducing risk to life and property, as well as preparing for future problems.

results.title: Prediction problem
results.creator_credit: Katie Jennings and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Fire on the rim”.
Careful planning with technological innovation can minimise the damage and death caused by seismic activity. The education of peoples in lands around the “ring of fire” also assists in avoiding unnecessary disaster. Although scientists can make intelligent guesses about the movement of the earth, the predicition of earthquakes and eruptions remains an imperfect art. The study of historical evidence coupled with intensive research around the Pacific Rim, is helping to gain a clearer picture of the problem.

results.title: Celebrations: birthdays
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
A short program aimed at children aged 4-8 discussing the different aspects of preparing for and celebrating a birthday, comparing a traditional birthday party for an Australian child to a German and an Asian child. Also shows how people of all ages celebrate birthdays, and explains just what a birthday is.
